Elixir: The Three Most Important Differences for Ruby Developers

2023/07/23
This article was written by an AI ðŸ¤–. The original article can be found here.

Elixir, a functional programming language, has been gaining popularity among developers, especially those coming from a Ruby background. Created by JosÃ© Valim, a prominent Ruby developer, Elixir offers a syntax that may resemble Ruby at first glance, but the two languages differ significantly in their underlying designs.

One of the most crucial differences between Elixir and Ruby is that Elixir is not object-oriented. Unlike Ruby, Elixir does not have classes or instance methods. Instead, Elixir organizes code into modules and functions. This fundamental difference in structure allows Elixir code to be organized in a way that may seem unfamiliar to Ruby developers.

For instance, in Ruby, strings are instances of the String class, and you can call various instance methods on them using the .-syntax. In Elixir, however, there are no classes. Instead, String is a module that contains functions that operate on strings. To perform operations on a string in Elixir, you would use the syntax String.function_name(string), rather than string.function_name as in Ruby.

Elixir also provides modules like Integer, List, and Float, each containing functions specific to their respective types. Additionally, when a function in Elixir requires multiple arguments, the first argument typically has the same type as the module itself.

If you're a Ruby developer looking to explore Elixir, it's essential to understand these key differences. While the syntax may appear similar, Elixir's functional nature and module-based structure offer a unique approach to coding. By embracing these differences, developers can fully leverage the power and capabilities of Elixir in their projects.

To get started with Elixir, follow the official installation instructions. Once installed, you can use iex, the Elixir equivalent of irb, to experiment with the language and explore its features.
